I am really enjoying these mugs . This coffee mug came as a 2 pack product . The first thing I must comment on is the packaging . Not only were these mugs shipped in an Amazon box full of bubble wrap but the box for the mugs was also double wrapped in bubble wrap . I 'm including a picture of the wrapped box since I was so impressed with the delivery handling . These mugs are actual glass but are not the weight of usual glass mugs . This can be an asset to individuals with strength disabilities such as arthritis . However , because of this lightweight design this is a cup best handled by adults due to the fragile nature . When it comes to the double-wall insulation the Epar & eacute ; mug performs flawlessly . While brewing coffee there was no condensation on the outside of the mug and the mug was cool to touch . The coffee stayed warm for 30 min which is much longer than some of my regular glass mugs . These mugs are large enough for the large cup setting on the Keurig coffee maker . My only concern with these mugs would be my grandchildren getting ahold of them and accidentally dropping one . I am not sure how well they would hold up in that situation. < br /> Pros :< br /> * Very light weight glass < br /> * Crystal clear < br /> * Smooth rim that feels good while drinking beverage < br /> * No condensation on outside of mug < br /> * Keeps beverage warm longer than traditional glass mugs < br /> * Very appealing to the eye < br /> Cons :< br /> * Fragile ( use caution around young children )< br /> * Extremely lightweight ( you may be ready to pick up a heavy mug but remember it 's very light )< br /> So , overall these mugs are 5 star for this over 50 woman with arthritis . I just have to be cautious around the grandchildren . Enjoy ! This \\" Scrigit \\" scraping tool is 6 3 / 16 in. long and is made of sturdy plastic . It has both curved and straight tips that can be used for removing stickers , cleaning crevices , peeling up wax , opening packages , and even disassembling electronics. < br />< br /> The edges are very sharp and do a great job . I have used an orange stick for similar tasks , but this tool works much better . It can remove a sticker from just about anything , and with minimal damage to the surface it is a attached to. < br />< br /> There is a pocket clip on the side , which is probably handy for many people , but I would prefer to have a plain tool , as the end without the clip is slightly easier to handle. < br />< br /> The Scrigit has earned its place in the pencil cup on my desk and in the kitchen drawer , and I wish I had another to keep in the toolbox. < br />< br /> Scrigit provided tools for evaluation and review .#### #### ####[([73], [72], 'POS'), ([113], [121], 'POS'), ([55], [62], 'POS')]

So far , so good !< br />< br /> TIPS : The lid should go on easily -- - if it does n't , you 've probably got something in the wrong place . The top handle with the little metal piece sticking out lines up with the bottom handle that says ' Open &# 60 ;&# 62 ; Close ' . The thin inner lid goes in so you can still read the engraved &# 34 ; Pull out to clean &# 34 ; . If the lid wo n't fasten , you 've probably got the narrow silicone gasket on upside down . Remove it gently and put it on the other way. < br />< br /> Be careful when you press the buttons - if your fingertip is on the right one and your fingernail hits the wrong one , it goes to the wrong setting .#### #### ####[([101], [99], 'POS'), ([33], [32], 'POS')]

I have only used it once and I am not impressed with the design . I 've worked in many kitchens and you need full oil coverage ideally if the food is to fry & cook correctly . The problem with the design is that it is too long and not deep enough to allow the drain function to work correctly , let me explain. < br />< br /> First , since the heat conductors are elevated from the bottom of where the oil is , you lose about an inch including when you place the basket in . The minimum & maximum fill lines for the oil are way too shallow due to the length of the fryer . I filled it to a little over the maximum oil level just to get better coverage although the organic , bone-in chicken breast I was frying was peaking out of the oil and had to be turned so it could completely fry on all sides . I was tempted to fill the fryer with even more oil but luckily ( I will explain below ) I had pretty much ran out of oil. < br />< br /> Second , the reason you cannot add go much over the maximum fill line ( the fryer is definitely big enough to hold much more ) is because of the easy drain function . When I fried all eight parts of my personal &# 34 ; Mock Pioneer Chicken &# 34 ; recipe , I used my metal strainer and got rid of most of the bigger pieces of batter floating around ( they tasted soooo goood !) . When it finished draining ( this feature is awesome by the way ) , the plastic container almost overflowed as I had put more than the maximum level of oil . This is what limits the otherwise decent fryer. < br />< br /> So , if anyone can please let me know what I 'm doing wrong ( I do n't see how I am ) please let me know . I bought this based on all the great reviews but I do n't see how you can comfortably fry much , my cast iron skillet holds basically the same amount of oil allowed . The best work around would be to fill it up with much more oil and NOT use the easy drain feature but this makes me think the heating element may not function properly as it was only designed to heat up so much oil. < br />< br /> I am open to suggestions , I even had some great chicken but it was much more of a hassle than I expected . I bought the fryer because it is such a pain to do in my cast iron / other pans but I may just stick to those.suggestions , I even had some great chicken but it was much more of a hassle than I expected . I bought the fryer because it is such a pain to do in my cast iron / other pans but I may just stick to those .#### #### ####[([268], [265], 'NEU')]

The replacement cost of the refrigerator filters was high and it was pricey for under the sink filters as well . The Zen water system gives you clean , clear drinking water along with healthy and necessary minerals for your body to function at its best. < br /> We put ours on our hot / cool water cooler . I had long taken a cavalier attitude that there was very little difference between rolling pins . Even when celebrity chefs were talking up their solid maple , simple cylinders , I stuck with my tried and true traditional one . But then , perhaps because of their contemporary stylings , I went out on a limb and bought KMN 's Aluminum Rolling Pin . Now , I can not use anything else. < br />< br /> Originally funded as a Kickstarter campaign , it is made of aircraft grade aluminum ( okay , that has it sold to all the men ) . It has great feel in your hands , and rolls very easily . Because of the textured surface you get a layer of fine flour that prevents sticking . You can also refrigerate the pin , and it will stay cold when working butter-doughs . The measurement markings make it super simple to roll your crust to the correct size . I live in a house divided ... My husband is the red wine drinker. . I 'm the white wine drinker ... Only occasionally do the two worlds meet :) When he DOES decide to enjoy a glass of white wine with me , he really wants it to be well chilled , as do I . Nothing worse than tepid or warm white wine , especially outdoors in the summer. < br /> Having to bother with messy ice buckets or chiller buckets on the table is just not the ideal arrangement so when we found this product online , we were excited to try it !< br /> We already used an aerator anyway so finding a chiller and aerator in one was a bonus since aerating really does make a difference in how the wine tastes. < br /> Kitchen Ezentials gave us an opportunity to try this 4 in 1 product at a promotional price to get our honest opinion and feedback so we were happy to be test subjects ! ;)< br /> We were impressed with the quality of the components of this - solid construction , simple but elegant design and easy to operate. < br /> Just wash the stainless steel rod and put it in the freezer for a couple of hours until its frozen then attach it to the aerator pour top and insert into the open bottle of wine. < br /> We tested this on both a bottle of room temperature wine and an already chilled bottle and , of course , the bottle that was already chilled stayed cold much longer - about an hour . The bottle of room temperature wine did cool down quite a bit once the chiller was inserted , but not nearly as much as the other. < br /> The aerator pour top is a smooth , clean pour without dripping and I really like that it seals off so you do n't have to keep putting the cork back in the bottle. < br /> This really is a great product to have on hand especially for summer outdoor dinners !< br /> I 've already added this to my shopping list for this Christmas for friends and family who are wine lovers ! This is a no brainer !< br /> Even if someone already owns one of these , having an extra or two is GREAT for dinner parties since there 's always more than one bottle of white wine !< br /> For companies who give their clients a bottle of wine for special occasions , this would be a wonderful addition to a gift basket :)< br /> Why did n't I find this sooner ?!!!< br /> Hope this was helpful info for you as you shop :)< br /> Enjoy ! e bottle of white wine !< br /> For companies who give their clients a bottle of wine for special occasions , this would be a wonderful addition to a gift basket :)< br /> Why did n't I find this sooner ?!!!< br /> Hope this was helpful info for you as you shop :)< br /> Enjoy !#### #### ####[([262], [271], 'POS'), ([208], [207], 'POS')]

Cupcakes and muffins are so fun and easy due to their single-serving size , and are some of my favorite things to make . A lot of the time , however , I find that I do n't quite have enough liners for whatever I am making , and I also dislike the waste of such a product . These cups were so appealing to me due to their ease of use , but even more so that they are re-usable . Much less waste , and I love that these are sturdy enough that I can even use these liners alone on a baking sheet , and not only to line a muffin pan as most paper or foil liners are used . These come in fun colors , and are n't all that difficult to clean , it is totally worth it . I have n't tried washing them in the dishwasher yet because they are so light , but I think in a cage where they can move around without floating freely around the dishwasher , they should be just fine . Soaking them is also easy and the grooves and edges are n't so deep that bits will get really stuck anyway . I think these are fun and a great addition to my kitchen , and they will get a lot of repeated use .#### #### ####[([7], [14], 'POS')]

I recently received one of these cookers as a gift . It seems to work great ... as long as you put the silicone gasket on the right way .... . * blush *< br />< br /> But when they say it 's a &# 34 ; 6-quart &# 34 ; or &# 34 ; 8-quart &# 34 ; , that is basically a lie . They insist that you do n't fill it above the MAX line of the inner pot . While the inner pot itself will hold 6 or 8 quarts if you fill it right up to the very brim , measuring to the MAX line limits you to 5 or 7 quarts , depending on which size unit you have. < br />< br /> Re : canning -- Do n't do any canning in it that would normally require a pressure canner . If you want to can high-acid foods in it ( normally suitable for water-bath canning ) , that is fine . Examples of high-acid foods : apples , applesauce , apricots , berries , cherries , cranberries , fruit juices , oranges , peaches , pears , pickled beets , pineapple , plums , rhubarb . ( Incl. jams & jellies. )< br />< br /> And you can only use PINT jars , not quarts . Mouth size does n't matter. < br />< br /> DO NOT can low-acid foods in it like asparagus , beans , beets , carrots , corn , hominy , meat , mushrooms , okra , peas , potatoes , seafood , spinach or squash , etc . Here is the reason , from the National Center for Food Preservation http :// nchfp.uga.edu / publications / nchfp / factsheets / pressurecookers.html < br />< br />&# 34 ; USDA does not have recommended processes for canning in a small pressure cooker . The recommendation for using USDA pressure processes for low-acid foods is to use a canner that holds at least four ( 4 ) quart-size jars . The research for USDA pressure processes for vegetable and meat products was conducted in pressure canners that are most similar to today 's 16-quart or larger pressure canners. < br />< br />&# 34 ; Pressure cookers have less metal , are smaller in diameter , and will use less water than pressure canners . The result is that the time it takes a canner to come up to processing pressure ( that is , the come-up time ) and the time it takes the canner to cool naturally down to0 pounds pressure at the end of the process ( known as the cool-down time ) will be less than for the standard pressure canner . The come-up and cool-down times are part of the total processing heat that was used to establish USDA process times for low-acid foods . If the heat from the come-up and cool-down periods is reduced because these times are shortened , then the heat from the process time at pressure alone may not be enough to destroy targeted microorganisms for safety . That is , the food may end up underprocessed . Underprocessed low-acid canned foods are unsafe and can result in foodborne illness , including botulism poisoning , if consumed. &# 34 ;< br />< br /> Have fun , eat well , but do n't believe everything the infomercials say . They lie like politicians .#### #### ####[([171], [169], 'POS'), ([174], [169], 'POS')]
As a homebrewer who stores all finished beer in kegs , I 've been using the CarbaCap ( or it 's predecessor ) for years . It 's an ideal way to bring homebrew to club meetings and social outings with a minimum of hassle . I also use the CarbaCap to force carbonate unfinished beer so that I can get an idea of how the CO2 will alter the beer 's characteristics and then appropriately adjust / blend ingredients . It 's also the easiest way to make soda and other carbonated beverages at home ( though you 'll need to buy CO2 cartridges or a tank as well as several other fittings ).< br />< br /> The product works just as it should . If you 've worked with kegs before , you 'll understand the simplicity of the disconnect . I did have one &# 34 ; Carbonater &# 34 ; Cap ( an earler version of the product ) that I used for a few years , but it developed a crack upon the manufacturing seam and would no longer hold pressure . I lived without it for several years , but then decided to buy a replacement . Upon opening the package , I saw the Warranty statement , so I decided to contact the company to see if they 'd replace my old one . They quickly answered &# 34 ; yes &# 34 ; and sent me a replacement . That 's about as good as customer service gets !#### #### ####[([35], [38], 'POS'), ([16], [6], 'POS')]

This product was a great idea just poor execution and design . The coasters are nice , they are ceramic tile front with a cork bottom . The image quality is decent but as other reviewers have mentioned they can smudge they lack crispness in the printing process . My main problem with these coasters is that they do n't really serve their purpose . Coasters should prevent water from you glass from getting on your expensive furniture . Because these coasters are ceramic tiles the water just flows from the glass to the tile to the furniture . They lack absorption qualities which leads to you ending up having to wipe them off before putting them away or spilling water remnants after you pick them up . We ended up just turning them upside down so that the cork backing is up . This gets rid of the water problem but we lose seeing the images . I would think twice before dropping money on these .#### #### ####[([54], [50], 'NEU'), ([24], [19], 'NEU'), ([84], [76], 'NEU'), ([84], [83], 'NEU'), ([29], [34], 'NEU')]

I actually have to leave the lid off mine for a little while because I am sensitive to really hot things , so I like to let it sit for a bit . Even with the lid off , in my air conditioned house , it stayed right at the upper temperature of drinkable for me for hours . Although the drinking lip is slightly awkward at first with the button to open the lid right under your lip , I found that I was able to get used to it after the first day . The pros of this thermos far outway that slight con . I have the worst cup holders ( possibly in the history of all vehicles !) and I love that I can close this and lock it . When I go around a corner , or stop , or anything pretty much besides drive in a straight line going 15 mph , I know that when it gets tossed onto the floor and rolls under the seat it wo n't leak all over everything . Updated review :< br /> Well , not even 2 years later , I 've had to change my rating for these containers . They started off working really well , but the difficulty with getting the lids off ended up being their downfall . After a few months of constant use , big pieces of plastic would break off from the corners or sides of the containers , I presume from the strain against the lids , rendering the containers ultimately useless because there was n't a leak-proof seal anymore . I no longer have any of these , as all of them ended up breaking in the same fashion and had to be thrown out. < br />< br /> Original review :< br /> Great for my needs , I use them every day to store pre-made meals in the fridge and in the freezer . They 're the perfect portion size for my lunches at work and seal very tightly . It 's a little difficult to get the lids off , which can sometimes be frustrating , but the benefits outweigh that one tiny annoyance . I have a lot of tupperware and glad reusable storage containers , but I end up using these the most because I love to make spicy stews and marinara-based pasta dishes , and these containers do n't get that stain that clear plastic does when faced with heat and red sauces . I have 4 of their bottles already , so I am clearly happy with their products . All of them are easily my favorite insulated bottles. < br />< br /> Zojirushi has this secret process that allows them to make their wall gap super thin and yet add a layer of high quality plastic to the beverage lining . This keeps the beverage inside more isulated than my Thermos and makes it 100 % easier to clean . This is the best 1L insulated bottle I have owned . The thin wall gap is great because it keep the overall size down considerably . This one liter bottle would be a beast if not for that . ( also keep in mind that his model has a neoprene &# 34 ; Slip case &# 34 ; that adds bulk as well - but is much easier to hold. < br />< br /> This is an extremely high quality product . I would say on par construction wise with Thermos but the design is very Japanese - well thought out and details like the slip cover , have perfect stitching etc. . I am not sure if Thermos offered this slip cover they would do such a perfect job . if you are familiar with Zojirushi , you already know this . If you are not , I suggest you take the factory tour on youtube and compare to the Thermos tour . You ca n't make a bottle this good without really caring about what you are doing . I am not saying Thermos does not make great product , because they do , it 's just Zojirushi seems to really care about every detail . There seems to be more thought . For instance , when my best Thermos is sitting for a while with a cold beverage , the top will not open when I press the button - there is some negative pressure that all bottles have . The Zojirush has the same pressure problem , but they fixed it and the bottle always opens up . Small details. < br />< br /> Note : This IS 100 % a Japanese import , even though this is not made in Japan . The packaging and design are clearly intended for the Japanese market , so this model is not sold in the US . That could be why the quality is so high ? ? ( my other bottles are Japanese imports so I ca n't compare to US models )< br />< br /> This world market is the best part of Amazon !! !#### #### ####[([265], [269], 'POS'), ([159], [158], 'POS'), ([201], [208], 'POS')]

First one caveat - I purchased this fry pan in 2014 and had been using it , but was offered another pan in 2015 free of cost by the seller , requesting a review . I have been using both pans now for about 6 months , and this review is my personal and honest opinion. < br /> So what 's good about the pan - one , it is non-stick and has kept being so even after about 6 months of regular use . And two , i like the red color . So I definitely recommend this pan for anyone looking for a stylish non-stick fry pan. < br /> What 's not so good - I realized soon after buying the pan that it is meant for gas stoves , not electric . Now , I have an electric range and because of the circular metal patterns on the bottom of the pan , you can scratch the stove top if you are not careful . I still continue to use it with my electric range , however , I am careful not to move the pan carelessly ... I also see that those circular patterns at the bottom have become somewhat discolored after use , but I do n't find that to be a big deal. < br /> Final say : Stylish and non-stick that continues to be non-stick , and therefore seems like a great buy for gas stoves ; in case of electric range , note that this pan can scratch the glass top if you are not careful .#### #### ####[([261], [266], 'POS'), ([102], [107], 'POS'), ([242], [234], 'POS'), ([109], [107], 'POS'), ([244], [234], 'POS')]

This filter clearly makes a difference in the taste of my water . I have taken the liberty of getting a few measurements of the water before and after treatment so we can see how much of a difference it makes for TDP and PH , but keep in mind that these are simply tools to help define water quality but do not by themselves determine the overall quality of your water. < br />< br /> TDP :< br /> Tap - 186ppm < br /> Mavea - 125ppm < br />< br /> So here we see a drop of about 60ppm of TDP . Keep in mind that some TDP is not necessarily a bad thing . There are normal healthy particles and minerals that exist in water and are good for you . The goal is to remove the bad TDP and leave the good TDP . RO systems can reach a zero TDP by removing absolutely everything , but that does not necessarily make it better for you . To really find out more about the quality of your water you would need to know what particles exist in your water. < br />< br /> PH :< br /> Tap - 8.22 PH < br /> Mavea - 7.00 PH < br />< br /> Generally you want to be around an 8.0 PH , so the PH of my tap water is actually pretty good . The Mavea is still in a reasonable range , but did drop the PH a tad. < br />< br /> I did do a taste test , and while I can still taste some of the chemicals after the Mavea treatment , it does taste better than the default tap water . Overall I would say the Mavea filter has been a positive , and I do notice things like how much calcium / lime exists after boiling a pot of water with tap water vs Mavea water . I would say the Mavea pitcher is a solid choice at a reasonable cost and will improve your water , but given these results I suspect there may be better filter options out there , though I could not point you to any other specific brand at this time. < br />< br /> For those considering the ZeroWater pitcher for it 's zero TDP I would highly suggest reading the reviews . While I have not tested the ZeroWater pitcher personally , the reviews indicate that it turns your water very acidic within a matter of only 1-2 weeks giving it a horrible taste .#### #### ####[([29], [35], 'NEU'), ([17], [21], 'NEU'), ([29], [21], 'NEU'), ([138], [133], 'NEU'), ([68], [67], 'NEU')]

Nice product from De'Longhi here , quality built . Looks and works like a professional grade machine. < br /> Very easy to use if you follow the instruction. < br /> Fill either the one cup , or two cup strainer with coffee , tamp it with the tamper for a nice even top , place it in the machine starting with the handle on the left and twist until the handle is facing middle. < br /> Turn on , wait for green light , dial the knob one more turn and voila , great Espresso. < br /> There are four settings - Steam , On , Make Coffee , and Make Coffee + Steam < br /> There is a nice large water reservoir that fits nicely inside , and a good trip tray that can be easily cleaned. < br /> The side steam swings out for frothing milk ( or whatever ) and the whole machine is pretty easy to use. < br />< br /> I have one problem , and for me it 's a big problem :-< br /> I 'm no Barista , so I 've never used professional Espresso machine . I 've seen plenty of course but never used one. < br /> I assume , because ( that 's what they do ) , they stop filling when the Espresso cup is full . This machine DOES NOT , and it 's a pain. < br /> Probably because I 'm used to pre measured quantities with Keurig K cups , or Tassimo pods , or even my Senseo bags - I sort of expected a decent Espresso machine to know how much 3-4oz was ??< br /> If you place your cup under the machine , and switch it to the little coffee cup sign , you will have to stand and watch it . Turn away and the cups overflowing , the drip trays filling up and it 's on a mission to empty the reservoir , shame really. < br />< br /> I had a couple of little hiccups too with the odd cup of coffee , at one point the machine made horrific noises and spewed water everywhere except through the coffee . I emptied the strainer and refilled and it worked fine , maybe a glitch. < br />< br /> Overall I gave it 4 stars#### #### ####[([127], [124], 'POS'), ([295], [305], 'POS')]

I used my Sushiquick Kit for the first time today and I love it ! I 've never attempted to make sushi before and I must say that the finished product looked very professional thanks to his kit ! First of all , the folding mat easily attaches to a base and the sheet of nori ( seaweed ) lays on the mat . I also purchased Kazu 100 % Organic Sushi Nori from Amazon . With a measurement of approximately 8.5 x 8.5 , the sheets perfectly fit on the folding mat . As an added bonus , a free lightweight bamboo mat was included in the package of 50 sheets ! Back to the sushi kit -- there is a plastic frame that is placed on top of the sheet of nori and this frame allows you to perfectly spread your rice and serves as a guide for the thickness of the rice layer . The included rice paddle makes this effortless . I found it even easier to moisten the paddle with some water while spreading the rice . There is an area at the top of the nori which will not be covered by the rice that will be dampened with water for sealing the sushi roll . After removing the frame , I added thin strips of carrots , cucumber and avocado on top of my brown rice and I was ready to roll ! The mat easily and neatly folds and seals the sushi roll and then there is a cutting guide that you place over the roll and expertly slice perfect portions ! It 's also helpful to dip your sharp knife in water while cutting each piece . There is a helpful instructional sheet enclosed with photos showing each step of using the Sushiquik Kit . If you 're interested in making your own healthy sushi at home and saving money as well , then I highly recommend that you purchase this kit !#### #### ####[([284], [277], 'POS'), ([302], [307], 'POS'), ([278], [273], 'POS'), ([154], [163], 'POS'), ([210], [219], 'POS')]

Got these to use while Kayak fishing . You do n't want glass when you 're kayaking and aluminum bottles are scary considering how much aluminum we already get every day , so this is the happy medium . Plus these are insulated ! They keep things cold after HOURS of being out in the heat with minimal covering . I keep mine in my tackle bag , with a flap over it to keep it out of the sun but that 's it . After 3-4 hours in the upper 80 's to around 90 , my &# 34 ; Ice 'd tea &# 34 ; was still pretty chilly. < br />< br /> Pros :< br />- Great for on the go type folks who need something to handle being smacked around. < br />- Keeps things fairly cool . Not as great as a Stanley thermos , but still good enough to last as long as it takes to drink it. < br />- Size is about the same as a regular bottle so no issues with it fitting in cup holders. < br />- Carabiner is good enough to rely on for the most part for strapping to a backpack or in my case : a tackle bag. < br />- Outer surface is AWESOME for those of us who kayak or have wet hands frequently . Keeps the bottle in your hand !< br />< br /> Cons :< br />- Does n't hold as much liquid as a regular bottle. < br />- It 's a little taller than regular metal bottles. < br />< br /> The cons are definitely minor . For my use I carry a cooler with the cold drinks on the back of my kayak and fill up these insulated bottles from there . They stay very cold over the couple hours it takes to down them and they stay cold enough for several hours after that. < br />< br /> Over all , I 'm * VERY * impressed . I will be buying more for sure if there are no other issues as I use them more .#### #### ####[([252], [251], 'POS'), ([46], [36], 'POS'), ([46], [47], 'POS')]

The Froz Sphere Ice Ball Maker is very good . Now , I found a couple of tricks to fill it . First , use a measuring cup ( or some other device ) to initially fill the lower half with water . Set the upper part of the mold in place , making sure it sets down completely . Then , the easy way to finish filling the mold is to use a very small funnel ( I ’ve had mine for years but I think you can get one at a beauty supply store ) , placing the end into the hole but not shoved in all the way , i.e. leave enough room for air to escape . Pour more water through the funnel into each hold . After just a couple of fill sessions you ’ll get so you do n’t spill or over-fill them . Good luck ! [[ ASIN : B00H8W54EK Froz Ice Ball Maker - Novelty Food-Grade Silicone Ice Mold Tray With 4 X 4.5cm Ball Capacity ]]#### #### ####[([110], [114], 'POS'), ([160], [150], 'POS'), ([158], [150], 'POS')]

PolyScience has helped bring the tools of Modernist Cuisine into the kitchens of amateur chefs . Certainly , any home modernist aficionado has a sous vide cooker . The Smoking Gun is the next must have device for your arsenal . It can help infuse hearty and delicate foods with smoke flavor , and very quickly . You add the wood chips to the smoking chamber , turn on the Smoking Gun fan , ignite the chips with a kitchen lighter , and smoke will come pouring out of the tube. < br />< br /> Because the smoke is released rapidly , you need to be prepared to capture the smoke in whatever food you are flavoring - ice cream , soup , cocktails , meats , etc . Also , you want to be working with your kitchen hood on full force , or outside , or turn off your smoke detectors . It is worthwhile to watch some of the vides online to give you tips on how to handle and make the most of your Smoking Gun . Adding smoke flavor to almost any food is tremendously easy with the Smoking Gun. < br />< br /> Not only can you test the flavors of different wood types , but you can use , spices , teas , herbs , really anything that is dry and flammable to give a little a something unique to your foods . The Smoking Gun allows an almost unlimited amount of experimentation .#### #### ####[([249], [248], 'POS'), ([39], [47], 'POS'), ([218], [209], 'POS')]

We had a mandolin slicer a few years ago , but got rid of it due to a dull blade and how annoying it was to wash . So I ’ve been hand slicing everything for the past couple year . I forgot how handy a slicer is ! Here are some thoughts on this :< br />< br />• Slicer design : When I first saw it I was n’t sure if I was going to like it because it does n’t have a stand , I have to hold it in my hand . I thought it might be difficult or annoying . I was surprised that it actually is n’t annoying at all . Even with my older slicer I had to stabilize it with my left hand anyway , so it ’s no different with this holding it with my left hand . The lack of a stand also makes it easier to clean. < br />• Slicing discs : I love the 4 discs that come with this . There are thin slices , thicker slices , French fries and shreds . They pop in and out of the slicer very easily and work extremely well . I personally really needed a slicer for my 1 ½ year old son . He only has 4 teeth and ca n’t eat firm fruits and veggies well . I love being able to slice produce in a variety of fun ways for him to eat ! This is perfect for us . I also am looking forward to making French fries with this . I have used my Paderno spiral slicer for shoe string fries and love it , but this will add some variety to my French fries and will make them easier to put on a baking sheet . The discs have a nice little holder that keeps them protected and keeps the blades at the bottom. < br />• Sharp : This is an incredibly sharp slicer . I had a very soft , nearly rotten peach that I wanted to test . I figured it would mush it up rather than slice it . Nope ! It came out in beautiful slices . Slicing harder items takes a little more push , but the blade is still plenty sharp to slice and cut it. < br />• Cleaning : I love that all of the pieces can go in the dishwasher and they are all flat so they do n’t take up much space at all . My last mandolin slicer had a big stand and took up a ton of space . For a kitchen gadget to get 5 stars from me it has to be : easy to use , functional , easy to clean and easy to store . I have a food processor attachment for my Kitchenaid mixer that does all of the things this mandolin slicer does , but it ’s HORRIBLE to clean and put away . We have it stored at the back of the pantry because we only use it for large quantities of food . It ’s not easy to clean or easy to store . I ’m grateful that I can use this mandolin slicer daily and it ’s not a big production. < br />• Safety : I ’m an ER nurse and if I got a dime for every person I ’ve got in that ’s cut off the tip of their finger with a slicer I would be retired . There ’s no way around it , these can be dangerous . I ’ve cut my finger , my husband ’s cut his finger , it happens . This one does come with a really , really effective piece for holding the fruit / veggie . I ’ve had some that do n’t actually hold the produce , they rip it and do n’t pull it through the slicer . This one has sharper prongs that pierce the produce fairly deeply to hold it in place . The green part of the holder can be lowered or raised to expose more of the prongs to pierce the product deeper if needed . This is the best holder I ’ve seen and if used right will protect the fingers well. < br />< br /> Overall , I have no hesitation giving this 5 stars . I love it , I love how easily it stores , I love how well it works and I love how it can go in the dishwasher . I was sent this to test and review . That never influences my review of products , I always give unbiased feedback. < br />< br /> We are obsessed with making healthier french fries with this slicer . I put some pics up . Here 's how I make them :< br />< br /> Preheat oven to 425 < br /> Slice up a potato with the thicker strip blade attachment < br /> Toss with olive oil and a pinch of salt < br /> Place on silicone baking mat , spread out so they are only one layer thin , not stacked < br /> I leave them in about 12 minutes , then toss them around , then every 6ish minutes I toss them around some more so they get evenly baked. < br />< br /> They are so delicious . You could add seasoning as well . I 've been meaning to use the smaller shred type blade to make hash browns , but have n't got around to it . Thanks for reading ! en meaning to use the smaller shred type blade to make hash browns , but have n't got around to it . Thanks for reading !#### #### ####[([46], [37], 'POS'), ([7], [6], 'POS'), ([310], [308], 'POS')]

This BasicWu instant read thermometer was sent to me free of charge . I agreed to test it and write an unbiased review. < br />< br /> The first thing I noted when I looked over the thermometer is that there is no clip . It is also not a \\" continuously updating thermometer \\" . That means , you cannot leave this clipped to the side of your pot to monitor the temp of your food . A candy thermometer MUST be self-updating and it must be very accurate as the temps go from too low up to too high very quickly once the pot begins to boil . Soft boil , hard boil , crack , etc ... stages are critical to recipes . Experienced cooks know how to test for the right stages without the thermometer , but novice cooks do not. < br />< br /> It will not work for oil or any other product you are cooking on the stovetop that needs careful temp monitoring. < br />< br /> What this does work on , and what it works well on is checking the temp of entrees , tv dinners , meat , cheese making , pasteurizing milk , etc ... It takes a few seconds to register the temp but it is good at it . I checked it against my calibrated thermometer and found this one is accurate within a degree. < br />< br /> Please do not purchase this if you need a candy or oil thermometer , this is not what you need . If you need something to spot check , this is an inexpensive option to tell when your food is properly cooked .#### #### ####[([3], [2], 'POS')]

So this is another product I 've wanted for a long time , but after receiving and using it , I 'm not convinced I 'm doing it right . The juicer contains instructions on how to cut the fruit before placing it in the device , and I followed them , but I think I had a different picture on how this juicer would work. < br />< br /> Its performance for keeping seeds out of my food is excellent - nary a seed sneaked through the holes , but I feel like the lemon halves still have juice left in them . Of course if I try to squeeze it manually after using this juicer , the seeds absolutely pour into my food , so it 's not very practical . I have n't decided what I 'd rather do , use the juicer and get less juice , squeeze manually and get seeds , or kind myself another one of those tiny mesh / metal strainers and strain through that . I 've always heard that having kitchen gadgets that can only do one thing ( two in this case , if you count squeezing lemons and squeezing limes two different things ) is a bad idea , and I honestly think there may be some truth to that . If I was n't so particular about the juice yield on my lemons , I could see no fault in the product , so if you 're willing to sacrifice a little juice for zero seeds , this is your product. < br />< br /> I received this for free or at a discount for product testing and review . My review is not guaranteed positive , it is an accurate representation of my experience with the product .#### #### ####[([236], [229], 'POS'), ([79], [81], 'POS'), ([156], [165], 'POS'), ([283], [274], 'POS'), ([233], [229], 'POS')]

The stated sizes are sometimes just the size of the pan , or the finished &# 34 ; cake &# 34 ; size , or sometimes they tell you the size of the box that the product is in , which is totally useless to the buyer . On this broiler pan , the stated size does not include the insert , which sticks out considerably . However , I 'm going to keep this because it will work in my big oven . I took a star away for incomplete information . I ordered the smaller pan like this . Wish me luck. < br />< br /> Here are the sizes , measured exactly . If all products had this information , it would be very easy to fit them. < br /> The complete broiler pan at it 's widest outside measurements as shown in the photo : 17-3 / 4 &# 34 ; x 11-3 / 4 &# 34 ; x 2 &# 34 ;< br /> The pan alone , at it 's widest outside measurements : 16-1 / 4 &# 34 ; x 11-1 / 4 &# 34 ; x 2 &# 34 ;< br /> The inside of the top taper of the pan14-1 / 2 &# 34 ; x 10-1 / 4 &# 34 ;< br /> The inside of the bottom taper of the pan 13-3 / 4 &# 34 ; x 9-1 / 2 &# 34 ;< br />< br /> I hope this helps you .#### #### ####[([162], [167], 'POS'), ([31], [38], 'POS'), ([173], [166], 'POS'), ([74], [67], 'POS'), ([196], [203], 'POS')]

Dislikes :< br /> The diffuser is too short . If you 're making one or two cups of tea you will not get a good steep . We took out the diffuser and just use the kettle to heat water. < br />< br /> Yes , it is programmable however , when heating less than a full kettle it will overshoot the desired water temp. by 10 - 15 degrees . I got around this problem by lowering the set point . If I want 175 deg water I set the program at 160 degrees . The problem with this work around is when I want to maintain the water temp at 175 , because the kettle will allow the water to cool to 160 before maintaining. < br />< br /> The base power connection to the kettle is a group of concentric raised rings that fits in the kettle 's concentric recessed circular grooves . When placing the kettle on the base I have to move the kettle around to get the two sets of rings to mesh . If I just set the kettle down on the base and do n't make the effort to properly seat it the kettle will not sit level , instead it will tilt at angle that is unsafe , especially when the kettle still has hot water in it . Other kettles Ihave used just have a simple post on the base that fits in a hole in the kettle bottom. < br />< br /> It is slow ! Compared to other electric kettles I 've used is is painfully slow . Also , the water will be at a full boil for a half minute or more before the kettle shuts off . If you remove the kettle before it shuts off and empty the kettle the program will resume heating even though there is no water . The kettle does have a dry pot safety shut off but it would be nicer when you are n't using the temperature program mode if it just turned off when you lifted the kettle. < br />< br /> Price . It is overpriced given the problems I 've encountered. < br />< br /> A small thing but still a thing ; the owner 's manual lists a desired water temp of 175 degrees for green teas . The program will only let you set the temp in 10 degree increments , 160 - 170 - 180 etc. < br />< br /> Another small thing ; push the lid release button and the lid only comes up half way . I also find the handle ergonomically awkward but it may be perfect for the average person. . It is heavy . If you have weak wrists you wo n't like the weight. < br />< br /> Likes :< br /> It looks good. < br />< br /> The beeper alert is not annoyingly loud .#### #### ####[([165], [156], 'NEU')]

In general I do not like Hamilton Beach products finding them somewhat low quality . I was very hesitant on buying it , but reading the reviews I decided to give it a try , especially considering Amazon 's great return policy. < br /> It makes a really full bodies coffee . With the same coffee beans , our old machine ( Mr coffee ) was not making nearly as bold as this one although we brewed both on bold setting. < br /> I do not know if I am lucky , or other reviewers are unlucky , but I did not have any spillage issues so far , neither leaks. < br /> If you are thinking of buying a cheaper product , I would definitely suggest buying this one instead . It does really produce much better tasting coffee . Since I have not tried $ 100 + machines , I have no idea how it would compare with them. < br /> Coffee does not have a burnt taste with this machine , even after 4 hours of keeping it warm. < br /> Note that the machine slides a bit if you do not hold it ( or put it next to wall ) and push the cup to fill. < br /> Machine makes a bit noise while keeping the coffee warm , but ou can only hear it while in kitchen . Not very noisy anyway. < br /> I wish the blue light on screen had a way to shut off , but even if there is a way I could not find it . If you are in a studio it might be an issue to have a bright blue light at night , but not a problem for us. < br /> In sum , If you are going to buy in this price range , or something cheaper , I would suggest giving this a shot. < br /> It is a bit bigger than regular coffee makers , so if the space is a big issue , you might consider it twice .#### #### ####[([284], [289], 'POS')]

I bought this dutch oven after reading from several customers that they use it for bread baking . This is exactly what I wanted it for as well . The books ask for a 4 quart dutch oven , but that does not seem to exist. < br />< br /> I had asked the question from others if I need to oil the pot prior to placing the dough inside . The reason I asked what that once before ( with a larger Dutch oven I own ) I had placed the dough inside the cold Dutch oven and let it rise before placing the vessel in the preheated oven . The bread was terrily stuck. < br />< br /> Once I read that the Dutch oven must be pre-heated and then the proofed loaf goes in the hot vessel the problem of sticking was solved . There is not sticking . And while the proofed loaf collapes somewhat during handling and transfering , it does rise nicely during baking . The crust is heavenly , similar to the breads I grew up with . YESSS !!!!!< br />< br /> This is a quality pot . Another reviewer mentioned the comfortable handles and large knob , an important factor when using heat safe gloves . This pots shines in all aspects . Well worth the money , I am thrilled with its performance .#### #### ####[([200], [203], 'POS'), ([219], [210], 'POS'), ([197], [206], 'POS'), ([143], [140], 'POS'), ([211], [210], 'POS')]

I started using the Contigo mugs about 2 years ago or so . I am an inveterate coffee drinker and enjoy sipping on a large cuppa for most of the morning . I grind my own beans and use a french press so need a container worthy of my brew and the Contigo is the only way to go . So , I was recently on a housewares shopping trip at Target and they had the new and updated Contigo mug . Considering that my current one is a bit chewed up from constant use and abuse I decided to treat myself to the new one and I am absolutely delighted. < br />< br /> Like the original Contigo the drip free drinking system is unparalleled . First , because of the simple design , drinking with the cup is very natural . No flipping of levers or weird positions to hold your hand . Your fingers naturally just press the button as you bring it to your coffee hole . And if the button is not pressed , you cannot spill your coffee . Really , you just ca n't . When I am asked about why I only drink from this mug I take a sip then flip the coffee cup over my head . Never a drop gets in my hair. < br />< br /> Now , the new design actually has a bit of a different curve to the spout and that makes drinking even more pleasurable . The new locking feature seems to be a bit of overkill to me but I could see it being useful if you are dropping this into your bag or something like that . The drink also seems to flow a bit more fully than in previous models. < br />< br /> The full seal along with a quality vacuum bottle keeps your drink warm for as long as possible . I usually pour my first cup at 6am and have been able to still drink it warm at lunch. < br />< br /> The best part is that they fixed the one complaint I had for the previous contigo which was access to the drinking mechanism for cleaning . You used to be able to get to it but only with a small brush . Now it is easy-peasy with full access from an easy to use mechanism. < br />< br /> Definitely get the brushed aluminum finish for a few extra bucks if you care what yourcup looks like . The matte finish ones will flake on the bottom after repeated cup holder insertion and removal. < br />< br /> So yes , pay the money for a coffee cup that you will be truly happy with . The first time a co-worker knocks your coffee cup over and the Contigo does n't let any drip out onto your shirt will save you the extra money you spent . If you are a daily coffee drinker , going back and forth to the office the contigo is a must buy .#### #### ####[([41], [40], 'POS')]

This is a nice set . Both of the tools are brushed stainless steel . They have a good , solid feel to them and the handles are easy to grip . Both have sturdy hooks on the end to hang them and you really should . They 're too pretty to hide in a drawer. < br />< br /> The peeler is a design that 's new to me . It has a &# 34 ; shield &# 34 ; to deflect the peelings and it 's SHARP . The little slicer on the end is handy for removing potato eyes and other imperfections . I 've peeled potatoes and carrots and zuchinni with it and it does a fine job . Takes off the peel with very little waste. < br />< br /> The other implement is a &# 34 ; Julienne &# 34 ; slicer and it 's two sided . One side has finer teeth and the other has coarser teeth . You simply draw it down the side of the veggie ( a zuchinni , say ) and it quickly cuts it into strips . Now here 's an interesting thing and if you are scientifically trained , you may understand it . It has me puzzled . The blades on both sides are quite sharp , but the finer teeth produce a wide strip , while the coarser teeth create narrower strips . However , both are pretty for salads or vegetable dishes. < br />< br /> There 's a third kitchen tool in the set which is n't in the picture . It 's a small cleaning brush with a great ergonomic handle and stiff , metal bristles . It 's handy for cleaning the peeler and cutter ( although most of the time rinsing them under the faucet does the job ) and you 'll find plenty of other uses for it , too . Just treat it with respect . Those bristles are sharp !< br />< br />***** I was given a free sample of this product . The seller offered nothing but the sample and asked for nothing but an honest opinion. **** This is an attractive , useful set of kitchen tools . Nice for a shower gift or a house-warming . If you 're lucky , they 'll invite you back to eat some of the food .#### #### ####[([35], [34], 'POS'), ([261], [259], 'POS'), ([13], [12], 'POS'), ([78], [68], 'POS')]

Good tea brewing system . Is this method any better than just heating up water and filling up any old pitcher or a few mason jars with tea bags ? Not really , in my experience . But this kit just makes the process a little more streamlined and easier , I guess , especially if you want to cool down the brew by shaking it with ice ( which is this kit 's calling card I guess ) . I load up about 7 or 8 tea bags and brew according to their directions . Slightly ventilating the top lid after pouring just-under-boiling water in , and then spinning the cylinder that holds the tea bags a few times. . It brews really good tea . Have lots of ice ready though . When I do two batches in the two pitchers , the ice required to cool down the brewed tea during the &# 34 ; shaking process &# 34 ; depletes my refrigerators ice , leaving very little to put in a glass for iced tea . Bummer . Hopefully your fridge has more ice capacity !< br />< br /> The only faults I can find here are in the pitchers . A couple things . ( 1 ) Shake these pitchers with ice over a sink . No matter how tightly sealed my lids are ... they still leak a little bit and drip while I shake . Not a lot , just enough that I feel I have to do it over a sink . And ( 2 ) the pitchers do n't clean well at all . They always look spotty or slightly stained . I ca n't get them looking clean . It 's just the plastic staining , and I know they 're actually clean , but they do n't look so clean no matter what I do. < br />< br /> But I like the fruit infuser basket , and the tea cylinders seem well made to last . And while not ground-breaking , this system works well enough and there 's not much else to say !#### #### ####[([24], [19], 'POS'), ([175], [170], 'POS')]

As Fall approaches I took out my slow cooker and found the cord was smashed . I perused the slow cookers on Amazon and found Cuisinart had some excellent reviews . I purchased it and tried or if my favorite recipes . This slow cooker is easy to use , the settings are quite simple , some recipes came with the slow cooker . Almost everywhere has a slowcooker , get it out and try this recipe that I love . It feeds a crowd. < br />< br /> SLOW COOKER SOUTHWESTERN BEER CHILI < br />< br />( makes 10 servings )< br />< br /> Ingredients < br />< br /> 3 tablespoons vegetable oil < br /> 2 medium yellow onions , diced < br /> 1 medium red bell pepper , diced < br /> 6 gloves garlic , chopped < br /> 2 small cans corn kernels no salt added , drained < br /> 1 / 4 cup chili powder < br /> 1 tablespoon ground cumin < br /> 1 tablespoon cayenne pepper < br /> 2lbs lean ground beef < br /> 1lb hot Italian sausage < br /> 1 1 / 2 teaspoons kosher salt , plus more to taste < br /> 1 28oz can diced tomatoes < br /> 1 can tomato paste < br /> 1 bottle lager ( Sam Adams work very well )< br /> 1 cup beef broth < br /> 1 tablespoon light molasses < br /> 2 15oz cans kidney beans , drained and rinsed < br /> 4 small jalapeno chili peppers , seeded , stemmed , and diced < br /> 2 arbol peppers , seeded , stemmed , and diced < br /> 3 teaspoons minced chipotle peppers in adobo sauce < br /> Directions < br />< br /> In a large skillet over medium-high heat , cook and break apart the ground beef and sausage . Cook until beef is evenly browned , and sausage is cooked ( about 8 or so minutes ) . Drain and discard any excess grease. < br /> Combine the remaining ingredients in the slow cooker . Cover , and cook on low for 10 hours , or high for 4 hours. < br /> To serve , garnish with cheese and serve with sour cream . From 12 tomatoes < br />< br /> Recommended . prisrob 08-31-15#### #### ####[([133], [132], 'POS'), ([68], [61], 'POS')]

Absolutely love this all in one < br /> Kitchen Kreations Stainless Steel Salt and Pepper Grinder ! My older individual mills are now the kitchen mills. < br /> Some things that folks might consider if they 're comparison shopping grinders :< br />- In my opinion , the grinding mechanism on these probably is not ideal for heavy kitchen use - I prefer steel or ceramic burrs , and these appear to be a plastic type material -- my experience with plastic burrs is that they do n't hold up to long term hard use - but - we 'll see , maybe these will be the exception. < br />- The grinding action ( where you put your hand to grind ) being at the bottom of the cylinder is a little odd and counterintuitive to me , also guests have been confused by it . Not a big deal , but a little different than standalone grinders , and possibly annoying for people who do n't adapt well to change :- D < br />- The caps , which * are * a good idea as far as cleanliness & good looks , are actually a bit of a P.I.A. to deal with at the dinner table - they are a little snug to take off and when removed , do tend to go missing easily , as they are unmarked , rather small generic looking circles of steel . I 've found mine in the trash a few times . Again , not a major issue , but kind of an annoyance in my world . My rating reflects these tiny issues in usability - not deal breakers , but could be just a wee bit better . Fairly well made , very light kettle . I feel like it is a little expensive for grade and size . The metal is fairly thin and feels lightweight for stainless steel 18 / 8 . So far no issues with it . I like the way it looks , but you have to be careful about touching the knob on the lid if you had the burner on the highest setting , because it gets hot . I have learned to heat the water on lower settings ( I have a gas range ) . It does appear sturdily made . And I have left it sitting on the stove with water in it for a day or so and no rust anywhere when I would wash and dry it . After reading so many positive reviews touting this kettle as having a good bit of heft to it I wonder if I got the same item as the other reviewers . I have some very good stainless silverware . The butter knives are large and one piece and I had two of them in one hand and this kettle in the other and they seemed to weigh the same . That does not equate to &# 34 ; heft &# 34 ; . In my opinion all the weight comes from the handle and the knob on the lid . I am satisfied with it , but for the price and the grade of the materials I would not recommend it as a bargain , and had I had it in my hands before buying it , I would n't have for the price I paid . I feel like it worth a good ten , fifteen dollars less than its asking price .#### #### ####[([19], [25], 'NEU'), ([22], [28], 'NEU')]

This is the best espresso machine I 've ever had ( and I 've already had several ) . I 'm a coffee addict and i can only say i get impressing results with this machine ( I pair it with a Capresso 560.01 Infinity Burr Grinder ) . Truly my coffee , espresso , americano , capuccino and latte 's are absolutely incredible ( much better than what you get a starbucks , for example , and i mean using starbucks coffee , you will still get much better results . Not that I am a starbucks fan but it 's a pretty fair starting point for most people ) . Anyway the bottomless filter is my favorite , yes you will see * a lot * of people complaining that you 'll get coffee spray all over the place and how much a mess you 'll have ... Believe me it 's just a matter of having the right grinder and mastering the tamping , that 's all . Yes it will take probably 1 or 2 weeks but after that you will be impressed . I do n't care too much for the pressurized filter since the coffee you 'll get is more standard and you 'll have to use a lot more coffee to get a strong shot . Just do yourself a favor and use the bottomless filter . It 's way worth it . Also I was having a lot of issues with frothing , i just could n't get any foam at all and i thought it was defective , but ( again ) the issue is on the user , turns out you need to just barely touch the milk surface with the frothing wand , and i mean barely touch it ( sometimes i think it 's even &# 34 ; before &# 34 ; the nozzle actually touches the milk ) . The key is that you should hear a fine &# 34 ; PSST PSST &# 34 ; sound and not a big &# 34 ; bubble &# 34 ; sound . I also find that i need to slowly lower the pitcher as foam is forming so that the top of the wand is always barely touching the surface . See this video for help : https :// www.youtube.com / watch ? v = UYFOE0qtoE0. < br /> I 've owned the machine for 4 months and so far everything is working just as new . I use it 2 or 3 times every day . No complains . Ca n't beat the price also .#### #### ####[([81], [89], 'POS'), ([257], [265], 'POS'), ([232], [231], 'POS'), ([23], [16], 'POS')]

Additionally research suggests that simply opening a bottle of wine and letting it rest in the bottle actually does n’t aerate it. < br /> The only way to allow your wine to breathe is by using a wine aerator pourer . Pretty neat little gadget . Tonight was the maiden run to tempt our 2 and 4 yr old grandkids into eating zuchini . The 4 yr old is adamant about hating squash . I browned 1 / 2 lb sausage , added diced onion to a skillet . The suction cups are great and stick to the counter . I had a rather long zuchini , so I cut it in half . The front center fits on a little tube that sticks out on the blade side . Then I slid the.handle side into the squash . With all the little point it stays securely in place . I turned the handle and in very little time I had a big pile of spaghetti spirals . I added these to the skillet and satire until al dente . I drained a little of the liquid off , then put a little over 1 / 4 jar of my favorite spaghetti sauce over the mixture . I plated it up and sprinkled it with parmesan cheese . As an adult I would rate this dish a 10 for flavor ... It was good . The kids said they were eating snakes . The 2 year old ate all of his , and my squash hater ate 2 helpings. < br /> I LOVE that the blades store in the machine . The kids have been grabbing stuff off the counter as I cook lately and these will be safely tucked away . I purchased this for my 5 year old . I had spent ages trying to find a bento box that was leakproof , kid friendly ( easy to open / close on their own ) , and would last a long time . After using it for a year ( and about to send it off for another year of school ) , I can say that this has been the perfect lunch box !< br />< br /> Pros :< br />* It has been leakproof for thicker things like yogurt , applesauce , dips and dressings ( it is n't recommended for thinner liquids like soup ).< br />* I personally think the compartment sizes are great , though your mileage may vary depending on the types of foods you like to pack . It was more than enough food for my kindergartner !< br />* The middle circle is a great size for a dip , or a small treat ( ex : it was the perfect size for a few almonds and raisins )< br />* It was very easy for my child to open and close. < br />* It fit perfectly in a Skip Hop lunch box with just enough room for an ice pack . ( Will need a larger bag than that if you want to add additional snacks or things like a thermos. )< br />* Makes it easy to pack healthy and fresh lunches . The labels ( dairy , fruits , veggies , grains , protein ) are also a cute visual reminder for balanced lunches. < br />* Less waste ! Everything is in one place - no need to worry about extra bags / packaging , or losing things like lids. < br />< br /> Cons :< br />* I have one with what I think is an older insert ... . which is more of an open design , and does make for a bit more work for clean-up . It was n't hard to clean up , it was just a pain to dry . ( I see that the newer ones have a flat bottom , which looks like it may solve that problem !)< br />* If you pack a lot of whole sandwiches , you will have to cut it up and put it in perhaps two of the spaces . I typically just did half of a whole wheat wrap in the top left compartment ... but if you pack a ton of whole sandwiches , then the Yumbox Panino might be a better option . I also own that one and love it . It is a great size for an older child or adult !< br />< br /> After a yearat school , there are some scratches on the top and bottom of the box . The hinges are still working perfectly , and the seals are going strong. < br />< br /> I highly recommend this lunch box !#### #### ####[([115], [118], 'POS')]

This is a serious tool for zesting citrus peels . For some reason , the word &# 34 ; microplane &# 34 ; really conjured up something a bit more petite in my mind . Instead , this is a monster that will demand substantial space in my kitchen utensil drawer . It also comes with a hole in the handle to hang it , if preferred . The zester also comes with a guard , but the guard is somewhat flimsy and snaps on / off , which makes me concerned about the longevity overall . I would have preferred a scabbard style protector instead , which would last much longer. < br />< br /> This microplane is efficient at zesting , there are no problems there . The handle is substantial and easy to grip . There are some other things that I do n't like about this besides the guard , however . The rear edges of the microplane are somewhat sharp , despite rubber guards on the corners themselves . Since this portion is not covered by the snap on guard , I can foresee this producing injuries should anyone reach into that utensil drawer while being somewhat distracted . Being made in China means that I am also somewhat dubious about the quality of the stainless steel and its long term durability . I have had other &# 34 ; stainless steel ' products from China that have rusted rather quickly . Time will tell how durable it turns out to be , and if it rusts , I 'll update my review . ( Our humidity in the South is tough on things that rust easily !)< br />< br /> If this had been paired with a scabbard style guard instead of a snap on one , this would be a five star zester , assuming it is not going to immediately rust , despite the size of this beast . I have to admit , the larger than expected size means that it is easier to zest oranges and lemons ( my usual victims ) . I have not tried it with hard cheeses or chocolate yet . I have also not tried using it over a dish that I am garnishing , which may prove trickier for me because of its larger size. < br />< br /> Disclaimer : I purchased this product with a promotional discount in exchange for my honest and unbiased review .#### #### ####[([172], [165], 'POS'), ([239], [232], 'POS'), ([199], [203], 'POS'), ([226], [232], 'POS')]

This is a really neat idea , but harder than I assumed it would be to use correctly . There is definitely a learning curve , and unfortunately these did n't come with any instructions . It took me actually reading other reviews to understand that there was a right way and a wrong way to put the top on to make it lock . So my first 2 attempts ended badly ( see first photo ) , then I read the review and tried again . In the beginning , where it was n't locking , extra water was accumulating , effectively turning 4 spheres into one giant funny looking cube . The third try was much more successful ( second photo ) , now knowing to fill the tray with more water than I thought I should , then put on the top piece and it forces the excess water into the top half of the balls to make the sphere . It still did n't work perfectly , but now I can see what needs to be done to make them right . It sure is a lot of work to get ice spheres , but if you really want them ( and I do !!) then it 's worth learning the tricks . This in a little spice / herb grinder , sturdily made and pretty hefty for its size . It 's well made , with no jagged or rough edges or seams . The top is magnetic and slips on / off , to show the blades . To use the grinder , you put spices on the blades and turn it over , twisting the grinder . The section below the actual grinder holds the ground up spices , and you can get to it just by unscrewing that section . The very bottom section is a pollen catcher - there is a mesh screen between the third and bottom sections that filter out any larger particles , trapping the smallest particles ( and pollen ) in the bottom compartment , and a little scraper to get the smallest pieces out. < br />< br /> The one downside is that it does n't come with any instructions , so if you 're not familiar with how to use or clean it , you might be lost . If they can add instructions , I would upgrade this to five stars , but my own confusion and frustration as I figured out how to use it automatically knocked it down a star . I ended up having to find a video on another similar spice grinder 's product page to figure out how to use it , which should n't be necessary. < br />< br /> I received this product in exchange for an honest and unbiased review#### #### ####[([258], [257], 'POS'), ([129], [120], 'POS'), ([250], [257], 'POS')]

This is a big cleaver ! I like the fact the edge has some curvature to it , so you can rock it while chopping vegetables . It 's also heavy ( 32 ounces ) . Was delivered sharp enough to go through Chicken Keel bones with ease but for finer chopping tasks like vegetables , I took it to a 1200 grit Japanese synthetic stone for further refinement . If you are looking to buy your first cleaver , this is a good choice for the money as it is not too pricey yet I feel there is plenty of quality here for a utility chopping knife , or you can use it as a cleaver , for getting through large cuts of meat , but I bought it primarily for general chopping in the kitchen , like I would use a traditional 8 &# 34 ; chef 's knife , though between these two ( this cleaver and a chef knife ) , the chef knife will be a lot nimbler . Despite the heft , it 's a fun knife to use in the kitchen for smaller tasks < br />< br /> Know this , the material of the blade is not stainless steel . Product description says it 's cast iron . To me , it 's carbon steel meaning when the knife is not in use , keep a coating of food grade oil on all metal surfaces , so it wont rust . I 'm using tea tree oil as I have a good size bottle of it . Forewarned is forearmed . I 'm also keeping the wood handle treated with a homemade wood preservative I keep on hand for wood cutting boards , 50 / 50 beeswax and mineral oil , because the wood handle is only stained and not sealed . You could shellac it or spray a coating of clear Krylon to protect the wood , or even just use food grade oil , rubbed into it , so it wont dry out and crack . Remember , this is an economical cleaver , the blade is thick and has plenty of metal there for future honing 's so it wont wear out in the long term , unless you 're a tradesman and use daily and hone accordingly . Even then , it will last a good long time IMO < br />< br /> FWIW , I did n't have a proper knife block that would accommodate this cleaver so I bought this magnetic knife rack http :// www.amazon.com / gp / product / B00WGKR7NK ? redirect = true & ref _= cm _ cr _ ryp _ prd _ ttl _ sol _ 2 from Amazon to hold it < br />< br /> If you are going to buy this as a general cleaver in the kitchen and want to use it for smaller work like chopping vegetables and you have smaller hands , I would look to one of the smaller cleavers made by the Thunder Group . The wide blade makes short work of picking up the vegetables you just chopped , negating the need to use both hands to move your chopped work into a bowl. < br />< br /> This is a large cleaver and is heavy to use since it weighs in at 32 ounces , but if you have large hands and want a fun cleaver to use for general chopping and do n't mind maintaining the carbon steel blade ( keeping it oiled between uses ) so it wont rust , I highly recommend it < br />< br /> I posted a pic showing two cleavers ... the other cleaver is a 7 &# 34 ; cleaver I bought through Amazon , this one http :// www.amazon.com / gp / product / B002NQP13K ? psc = 1 & redirect = true & ref _= oh _ aui _ detailpage _ o07 _ s00 < br />< br /> This other 7 &# 34 ; cleaver is half the price of the thunder group ($ 15 vs. $ 31 ) and the blade is stainless steel on the 7 &# 34 ; Update International cleaver , & has a nicer riveted handle that fits well even in my large hands but if you look at the edges on these two cleavers , only the thunder Group cleaver has a rounded edge profile . The 7 &# 34 ; Update International cleaver 's edge is flat ( straight line ) between the toe and the heel , so not made to be used as a rocking type of cleaver . Instead , it 's made to cut through large pieces of meat , and it does that well . You 'll have to forgive me , it looks like I 'm reviewing two different cleavers here , towards the end of this review for the Thunder Group Cleaver yet I included the picture showing both cleavers that Amazon sells , both of which I own and have used and I 'm merely pointing out the differences and if you want a cleaver that can be used on a cutting board to chop vegetables , purchase the thunder Group cleaver , it 'll do a better job of doing a rocking type of chop , despite what some may view as having some negative features , being an all carbon steel blade that is susceptible to rusting , if proper care is n't used , but if you are like me and like to craft edges on your knives , I prefer an all carbon steel blade to a stainless steel blade for ease of honing purposes . Also , the edge on the 7 &# 34 ; cleaver has a hollow grind to it just above the edge , and not as easy to sharpen as the more angular blade on the thunder Group cleaver , where it 's just two bevels intersecting , w / o any hollowness added at the edge . Sorry , but I digress =:-)#### #### ####[([43], [38], 'POS'), ([281], [280], 'POS'), ([166], [172], 'POS')]

I 've been a tea-drinker for a long time and started brewing loose tea as soon as the Internet came along and I could get it . I 've had at least four other types of personal tea-makers and this is hands down the best. < br />< br /> I do n't know how borosilicate glass is manufactured , but it is noticeably different from conventional glass . It LOOKS fragile , but it 's tough . I 'm sure you can break it , but I 've tapped it rather forcefully against hard surfaces without a crack . It also holds up to high temperatures much better than regular glass. .< br />< br /> This design is lovely , while being totally practical . The infuser fits down into the cup and the glass lid keeps the water hot while the tea leaves are steeping . When it reaches the desired strength , you take off the lid and place it upside down and the infuser rests in it . No drips . When I received this , I envisioned that I would be pouring the tea into a mug . Who wants to drink tea out of a cup with no handle ? Much to my surprise , I do ! . Because the cup is double walled , you can cradle the cup in your hand and feel only a pleasant warmth . It 's a delightful experience. < br />< br />***** I was given a free sample of this product . The seller offered nothing but the sample and asked for nothing but an honest opinion. **** If you brew loose tea , this is a great system . It also comes beautifully packaged If you want to please a tea-drinking friend or relative , give them this brewer . It 's so modestly priced , you can afford to include a package of good loose black or green tea . I promise they 'll love you for it . I know I would .#### #### ####[([37], [36], 'POS')]

I would spray the insert with coconut oil spray , and then steam anything I wanted ; veggies , frozen meatballs , frozen pot stickers , etc . I did n't have a problem with the food , but the clean-up was rather an ordeal . Actually , not that bad , but annoying enough that sometimes I would n't use it . This steamer is so awesome I am steaming food a couple times a week . I put a couple tablespoons of water in the bottom , put whatever I want to steam in the insert , place the lid on loosely , and then microwave for a few minutes . This is a beautiful 3 piece set offered by EBI Homegoods . I was actually really impressed with the quality and look. < br />< br /> Perfect for a wedding shower or house warming gift with it 's included mesh metalic ribbon cinch bag . Each piece is made from a durable stainless steel . It is light in weight . The silicone heads of both the spatula and whisk are BPA free and can withstand heat up to 480 degrees Fahrenheit. < br />< br /> The spatula is about 11 &# 34 ; long . The silicone head is secured by a long flat stainless steel insert . The head can be removed for easier washing . It is dishwasher safe . The entire head is a smooth surface . The high grade silicone does not appear to absorb smell or stain . Egg is still a challenge and sticks to the spatula , but didnt require scrubbing as with any other spatula . Just a rinse and quick wipe and it came off easily . There is a stainless steel hoop at the end of the spatula for hanging your spatula on a utensil rack , or you can just store it in a drawer , which is what I do. < br />< br /> The whisk is about 10 &# 34 ; in length . The silicone hoops are flexible and wo n't scratch your bowls . Whisking scrambled eggs in the actual pan has never been easier or safer . No more bits of non-stick coating scratched off in my breakfast . Very easy to clean as well . The whisk also has a hoop on the end of the handle for hanging. < br />< br /> The cake tester is about 7 &# 34 ; long . The probe itself is stainless steel and has a silicone head that says &# 34 ; Cake Tester &# 34 ; . The silicone head on this does n't come off for cleaning , but it is easy enough to wipe clean with a little soap and water. < br />< br /> While I use my set for my own baking and cooking needs , I can imagine someone taking this trio and making a gift basket with it including mixing bowls and measuring cups as a house warming gift or even for a bridal shower . I knew the cork was hiding somewhere underneath the shiny metal foil firmly affixed to the bottle neck , shimmering like an elusive mirage . However , attempts to remove this stubborn oenophilic chastity belt with a knife or a scissors proved futile , and on one occasion practically fatal . While awaiting paramedics to arrive after severing a major artery and collapsing face down in a puddle of my own blood , I vowed to never again risk my own life attempting to remove another dastardly wine foil. < br />< br /> And so I was sadly relegated to drinking screw-top bottles of wine , doomed to live a pathetic , solitary life . I soon learned that nobody wants to be with a man who only drinks screw top or boxed wines ; that 's no a man , that 's a child . Feeling hopeless and lonely , I decided to cash in my life savings and move to Minsk where I could spend the rest of my days drowning my sorrows in bottles of vodka with easily removable caps. < br />< br /> In a shocking twist of fate , on the morning of the day I was set to leave on a one-way flight to Minsk with no possibility of return , I happened upon an advertisement for a life-saving product called Edgy . Edgy provides a safe , reliable way to remove wine foils with no messes and no accidents . Now , the fancy bottles of wine that used to mock and taunt me are crushed like ladybugs . I guzzle Domaine Leflaive Montrachets , Screaming Eagle Cabernets , and Henri Jayer Richebourg Cotes de Nuits like bottles of water , all thanks to Edgy . Yes , I am now drunk literally all of the time , but I 'm also happily married ( I think ) to a woman ( I think ) who is stunningly beautiful ( I think ) . And it 's all because of Edgy. < br />< br /> So thank you , Edgy , for saving my life .#### #### ####[([258], [267], 'POS'), ([275], [265], 'POS'), ([286], [283], 'POS'), ([258], [265], 'POS'), ([210], [213], 'POS')]

Had high hopes , but this cooker is just not that well designed . There is a regulator ( not the knob ) that eventually lifts in place based on the pressure , locking the lid when it starts to get pressurised . This component sometimes would not lift ( if for instance , using a small amount of water or food ) and effectively overcook whatever you put inside it . I have to baby the pressure cooker and occasionally use a screw driver or pipe cleaner to grab the regulator and give it a pull to lock it. < br />< br /> Steaming function never worked . Set it to one minute or 10 minutes either way it will continue to steam until it over heats or destroys your food < br />< br /> There is a small plastic cup that attaches on the side of cooker for collecting moisture . It 's tacky and held in place with plastic ridges ; on my unit these did not work and the slightest touch causes the cup to fall off . Used a magnet to hold it in place. < br />< br /> The times the pressure cooker had no issues the food was delicious and it worked as advertised . But I need something reliable and this is not it .#### #### ####[([148], [157], 'NEG'), ([148], [141], 'NEG'), ([206], [208], 'NEG')]
